So a while ago on this server I was in a very engaging conversation about monadic and effective descent in which I learned a great deal, but I had a lot more to understand before I could fully grasp it. It was a while ago, so I've certainly forgotten a few things (and so I might get a few things wrong here) but I wanted to revisit the concept in light of another concept I learned about more recently.

This concept is that of local objects and localization, which we covered extensively in the previous discussion on model categories. An object XXX is called ggg-local (for a morphism g:Y→Zg: Y \to Zg:Y→Z) if Hom(g,X)\mathrm{Hom}(g,X)Hom(g,X) is a bijection (more generally, we usually refer to whole classes of morphisms). The function Hom(g,X):Hom(Z,X)→Hom(Y,X)\mathrm{Hom}(g,X): \mathrm{Hom}(Z,X) \to \mathrm{Hom}(Y,X)Hom(g,X):Hom(Z,X)→Hom(Y,X) reflects composition: "lifting" a morphism from ZZZ into one from YYY by composition with ggg. The fact this function has an inverse in this case means the opposite direction is possible- you can "descend" a morphism from YYY into one from ZZZ along ggg always. In a sense, a ggg-local object "thinks" that ggg is invertible, even if it isn't actually. Furthermore, the nlab page "descent object" defines the notion of a "descent object": given a morphism g:Y→Zg: Y \to Zg:Y→Z and an object XXX, the descent object is the set Hom(Y,X)\mathrm{Hom}(Y, X)Hom(Y,X) equipped with the function (or bijection, if XXX is ggg-local) Hom(g,X)\mathrm{Hom}(g, X)Hom(g,X).

More generally, if we are in a 2-category, then the descent object becomes a category (hom category). So here are the two questions I want answered. First, is the descent category Hom(Y,X)\mathrm{Hom}(Y, X)Hom(Y,X) in this 2-categorical case the same thing as a "category of descent data"? Secondly, if so, then in the usual case of effective descent, what is the 2-category we are set in, what are the objects XXX, YYY, and ZZZ, and what is the morphism ggg, such that Hom(Y,X)\mathrm{Hom}(Y, X)Hom(Y,X) is the category of effective descent data? Thanks!

Let me try to state the general pattern for 'descent' and 'descent data'. It's very general so what I say may sound a bit vague. When you have a map p:Y→Xp: Y \to Xp:Y→X of some sort, you can often pull things over XXX back to get things over YYY.

The first crude descent question is: given a thing over YYY, can you get it by pulling back a thing over XXX?

If you can do it, we say that thing descends to XXX.

A better descent question is: what extra structure must we give an thing over YYY, to specify how it comes from pulling back a particular thing over XXX? (Different things over XXX can give the same thing when you pull them back to YYY.)

The answer to the better descent question is to describe descent data for a thing over YYY, and prove: the (n-)category of things over XXX is equivalent to the (n-)category of things over YYY equipped with descent data.

Example. For a simple example of this pattern, let p:Y→Xp: Y \to Xp:Y→X be an open cover of XXX by contractible open sets

Y=⨆iUiUi open in X Y = \bigsqcup_i U_i \qquad U_i \text{ open in } XY=⨆i​Ui​Ui​ open in X

and say that a thing is a principal GGG-bundle. Then the descent question is: what extra data do we need to give a principal GGG-bundle over YYY (wlog trivial) for it to descend to a principal GGG-bundle over XXX? And the answer is: transition functions

gij:Ui∩Uj→G g_{ij} : U_i \cap U_j \to Ggij​:Ui​∩Uj​→G

obeying the cocycle condition

gijgjk=gik g_{ij} g_{jk} = g_{ik}gij​gjk​=gik​

So in this case descent data consists of transition functions obeying the cocycle condition.

We have already seen, in earlier conversations, how in this example descent data is connected to a certain monad, and to a certain simplicial object. This is typical! Indeed here's a pretty general descent question:

Q: Given a right adjoint functor U:D→CU: \mathsf{D} \to \mathsf{C}U:D→C that is monadic, what data do we need to give an object of c∈Cc \in \mathsf{C}c∈C to specify an object of D\mathsf{D}D that it came from?

And the answer is:

A: ccc must be equipped with a map α:Tc→c\alpha: Tc \to cα:Tc→c making it into an algebra of the monad T=RLT = R LT=RL, where LLL is the left adjoint of RRR.

This is called monadic descent. For more try these:

  • nLab, Monadic descent.
  • MathOverflow, Why are monadicity and descent related?

The first one features the example of principal bundles that I just gave. The second features a classic example from algebra, where some arrows are turned around - as usual when we go from topology to algebra. Here the descent question is: given a ring homomorphism ϕ:A→B\phi: A \to Bϕ:A→B, what data do we need to equip a BBB-module with for it to be of the form B⊗AMB \otimes_A MB⊗A​M for some AAA-module?

I became enamored with the second question in the special case where AAA is a field and BBB is a field containing AAA. People call this case 'Galois descent', and it has a special flavor because it becomes connected to Galois theory and something called Galois cohomology. However, it was easiest for me to understand this stuff when I realized it was 'just' an example of the general subject of descent. (Here 'just' is used in the way category theorists use it. In fact this example has a lot of interesting special features!)
Finally, I'll add that descent becomes even more fun when we switch from a 1-categorical setting (as in my examples above) to an n-categorical setting (like descent for stacks).

Thanks for the response. Let me see if I can talk through this!

Ok, let me try to tie everything together. A "category of descent data" is given as a hom object, which above was mentioned to be in the category of fibrations over CCC. I personally prefer working instead in contravariant pseudofunctors to Cat, and the two are equivalent anyways. So in the category [Cop,Cat][C^{op}, \mathrm{Cat}][Cop,Cat], there are three objects (contravariant pseudofunctors) to note. The first is what I will call SSS- this is the main functor that sends an object to the "stuff" over it (bundles, or what have you) and morphisms to the pullback operation (so for instance the functor that sends bundles to the pullback bundles along some morphism). The next is what I will call (−)/X(-)/X(−)/X which sends an object to the category of morphisms from it into XXX, kind of like a hom functor but more category-y. This is equivalent to the codomain fibration of C/XC/XC/X by Grothendieck. The final is the cover hx(−)h_x(-)hx​(−) which- well, I'm not sure exactly what it does so I could be wrong about this. But in some sense it should send an object to the set of morphisms from it to XXX that are in the designated cover. By Grothendieck this gives rise to the codomain fibration hxh_xhx​ detailed above.

Now we have the canonical inclusion i:hx(−)→(−)/Xi: h_x(-) \to (-)/Xi:hx​(−)→(−)/X and, taking this morphism with respect to SSS, we have the classic descent scenario. Taking hom categories, we get Hom(i):Hom((−)/X,S)→Hom(hx(−),S)\mathrm{Hom}(i): \mathrm{Hom}((-)/X, S) \to \mathrm{Hom}(h_x(-), S)Hom(i):Hom((−)/X,S)→Hom(hx​(−),S). As per usual, the latter is called the "descent object", in this case the "category of descent data". The former might be equivalent, at least in some sense, to S(X)S(X)S(X) itself (at least, if some sort of Yoneda-like result applies). From all this, it's my impression that "descent data" is then just a natural transformation from hx(−)h_x(-)hx​(−) to SSS. I think I can try to justify this a bit. First, if something like Yoneda holds, then there's a natural transformation (−)/U→hx(−)(-)/U \to h_x(-)(−)/U→hx​(−) for every morphism from UUU to XXX in the covering, which we can think of as a "part" of XXX. Composing with some hx(−)→Sh_x(-) \to Shx​(−)→S, we get a natural transformation (−)/U→S(-)/U \to S(−)/U→S.

Again, assuming something like Yoneda, this gives a single "stuff" over UUU. For instance, if UUU is an open cover of XXX and we are working with bundles over XXX, then this would be a trivial bundle over UUU by itself that we intend to later glue with other bundles over other open sets in the cover to get a whole locally trivial bundle over XXX. So given some hx(−)→Sh_x(-) \to Shx​(−)→S and considering all maps from pseudofunctors of form (−)/U(-)/U(−)/U to hx(−)h_x(-)hx​(−) seems to give a "decomposition" of an element of the category of descent data into a bit of "stuff" for each part of XXX given by the covering over XXX. My guess is that somewhere, somehow, in all this the transition functions and cocycle conditions can be found. But I could be completely off base with all this!

But this is false since (−)/A(-)/A(−)/A lands outside the image of Set in Cat. Thus (−)/A(-)/A(−)/A does not satisfy the Yoneda property!

Not a question, just want to summarize some of the thoughts I had over the weekend. I've thought about descent and locality a lot more, and I think I've figured out most of how it works. It all centers around the comparison function/functor S(X)→Hom(hX(−),S)S(X) \to \mathrm{Hom}(h_X(-), S)S(X)→Hom(hX​(−),S). If we think of S(X)S(X)S(X) as the set/category of global data, then we can think of Hom(hX(−),S)\mathrm{Hom}(h_X(-), S)Hom(hX​(−),S) as a set of collections of local data (data for each part of XXX) along with descent data (the gluing instructions for when parts might overlap).
